title: Is it possible to write a novel without character development, and still be a good story? - Quora

response.answer_text: Absolutely. Creative writing teachers who say “Your character must develop over the course of your novel” are doing the same thing junior school teachers do when they tell you “i before e except after c”, or “you can’t start a sentence with a conjunction”. They’re teaching a lie, because it’s easier than explaining a complicated truth. And because it’s a lie that works often enough to be worth teaching. There are plenty of great and popular novels out there where the characters don’t develop. A lot of them are genre fiction: detective novels, science fiction novels, horror novels. Some of them are considered great literature. Nobody changes in Moby Dick. However, character development hasn’t risen to such prominence by chance. These days, we, as novel-readers, like and expect to see characters grow. Agents and publishers like to see characters grow, and will be less appreciative of your novel if they don’t. So the answer is “yes… but know what you’re doing.”

I agree that character development is really important, and there’s no good reason to skip over it. One thing I wanted to point out is there’s some flexibility depending on what genre you’re writing. If you’re writing genre fiction like a Harlequin-type romance or a thriller, you can usually get away with less development. But if you’re writing about, say, a guy going on a long soul-searching motorcycle trip that culminates in him helping his ex- bury her dead cat, you need a lot of intricate details and ways to reveal character.
